narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about legal theories and concepts, as well as a variety of international case studies revolving around different aspects of law and society. It was great to have a combination of theoretical approaches to law and society, and applications of those theories in the real world.

I think the main take-away of this course were the sociology, anthropology and political science theories we read about weekly. All of the readings were so interesting, and really helped me build up a base of theoretical knowledge on these issues. Classes were basically in-depth discussions of these theories, and so I learnt even more than I did just by reading the texts.
Law & Society research framework, how to formulate an effective social science research question, nature of concepts, how law and social norms intersect or diverge

Professor Lazarev taught a nice framework for writing papers. I think that was beneficial. 
Did Professor Lazarev clarify the role of law and the role of society and their relationship? No.

Walking into this course I had never explored the law and society discipline at all. We covered a great amount of material in that field, exploring both the core concepts and the methodologies scholars apply.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
A strength of this course is that I got to see how the law interacts with different societies in different ways, which was very interesting, especially since a majority of the material focused on non-US contexts. It was great to really get an international perspective on law and society.
A weakness was that there was very little guidance in the course, especially with regards to grading and the final paper. I felt like I didn't really know what was expected of me in the class or how I should write the assignments.

The strengths of this course are the readings, and Professor Lazarev's passion for the subject. He is able to guide discussion really well, weaving in more empirical concepts into our debates about the concepts and theories we read. The main weakness, I think, is that the weekly student presentations often run out of time because they stick to a very set format. I think giving more students more freedom to explore a topic in the way they want (while still maintaining some ideas they should touch upon) while allow increased engagement. Sometimes, just going through concepts, arguments, alternative arguments, etc. was a bit monotonous.

The class is designed to help you produce a final project in accordance with the law and society research framework. I genuinely learned a lot from writing my final project  it helped me identify new research interests. The readings are often fascinating. 

However, I had hoped to glean new insights into the relationship between law and society in general, and the class didn't really allow for that. A group of students led discussion on each week's readings, but presentations were expected to follow a very rigid structure which prevented free discussion of the relationships between readings. As a result, the readings often felt disconnected from each other. I imagine that this was also a consequence of the project-based structure of the course. 

The class could definitely be improved if students only led discussion for about 10-20 minutes instead of the whole class, more opportunities for free discussion were built into the syllabus, each week's syllabus readings logically flowed from those of the previous week, and Professor Lazarev took on more of the discussion leading.

Strengths: I think the framework for paper-writing is good (how to organize papers into sections: the sections are good). I think that we read a lot of interesting material. I think that we occasionally had fruitful conversations. 
Weaknesses: This class was quite confusing. At the end of the day the class was solely about the readings. Thats fine for most classes, as long as they figure out some way to bridge them or to piece them together to create a cohesive idea that they explore. Law and Society in Comparative Perspective was not one of those classes. Frequently, I would find myself asking what the class is about, or why we were reading what we did. I think we needed to bring this class back to a larger theme what was it about society that affected the rules that we create? Or how does law affect the societies we make for ourselves? Are they explicit or implicit? I would love to diagram these affects on a map, or learn some cool categorization method, or otherwise have some useful method to process how the pieces of the class fit together as a whole. Instead, we had (although I know Professor Lazarev probably spent a lot of time on the class) a class that seemed lazily put together, a cookie-cutter method of understanding lackluster readings, and a shoddy, loose canon of works with little reference to each other.

This course does exactly what it should do. As with all courses that depend on the independent perusal of dense material, I think it could benefit from the occasional flipping of the classroom; students might do better in grappling with the material if first primed to look for particular patterns.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The weekly discussions and student presentations helped increase virtual engagement, but I think this engagement could be increased further by either cutting short the student presentations, or allowing more freedom in their format. I think I was most engaged during the discussion portion of the class, which sometimes felt really short if the presentations went over time.
Breakout rooms were a prominent feature of class discussions, but I felt that they were not very effective.

In this realm, little succeeded. Granted, COVID-19 times are hard, and I will give Professor Lazarev slack for that. At the same time, some of my other classes really were able to strike a great balance on Zoom. This class did not live up to the standard I had wanted it to in the beginning of the semester. It was a combination of low-energy (which was exacerbated by the fact that we were all on computer screens), discussions led through questions that were too vague, too narrow, or on readings so long and/or complex no one read them, and no help given to facilitate any human interaction or humanity. I didnt know any of my classmates by the end, and I think thats a problem. Class remained cold and unforgiving, and I hated it. 
Discussions were led by classmates each week, which helped somewhat; at the same time, it would have been helpful to tie them in together to have an actual idea of why we were doing these exercises. Nothing broke the ice among us. 

tl;dr it was hella awkward.
This functioned exactly like a traditional seminar, save for its online meeting format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I absolutely would recommend this course to another student, especially if you're interested in the role that the law can play in our society. This is not a "law" course per-say, but explores how the law interacts with societal issues and structures.

Maybe, if you're particularly interested in the law and society research framework and would appreciate an opportunity to undertake an independent research project. The class might also be better if it takes place in person in the future and allows more bonding between classmates?

No, I would not. Are you looking for a law class? Go to law school. Are you looking for a society class? Take something in the Anthropology or Sociology department. Are you looking for a senior political science course that will rock your mind? This class is not it. 
Ultimately, my critique of this class boils down to a few points. First, it was not clear in its thesis. Sure, there may be a Law and Society canon, but it would be helpful if we could have some clear understanding of the actual canon. We plugged and chugged, and our formula for digesting what knowledge I was attempting to glean did not sit well with my stomach. I dont know why we read what we did, and while they were cool articles, I feel like half of them were chosen because they had the word law legal or litigation in the title. 
Additionally, I did not know my classmates well, and I dont think that the Zoom format was conducive for learning in this class. This class could maybe work (that is a tentative maybe) in-person, but Professor Lazarevs teaching style is not conducive to Zoom. The class felt low-energy and impersonal.

This is a great course. One must be a comfortable reader of social science, and must be excited about the material. This course demands a high volume of reading, and it needs to be done relatively thoroughly.
